Comment:
6. ...Nxf6 is playable for black but White retains a solid centre and the advantage of the first move, and has a slight initiative with which Black has to reckon.

The game move offers black sharp counterplay along the g-file. However, the move loses tempo because Black will have to move the Knight in order to develop the bishop to g5

the best square for the bishop because at c4 the bishop will be harrassed with Nb6 and Bg5 to follow.
preparing for Bg5
a logical move to prevent Bg5 but it creates a weakness at g2.
attacking the weak point Black aims to complete his queen side development and then castle queen side.
this is an over extension which is easily attacked by black. This is a typical novice mistake as a rule you should never play this move without being provoked

? Pins the knight, increase control of light squares and prepares for ...h5 or f5.

9. ...h5! 10. gxh5 Qd5 and black is doing great.
planning to follow up with c4
I wanted to get this move in before I am evicted from the 5th rank
right now the game is equal. Black is cramped but has some counterattack going. White has a space advantage but no serious attack. Dispute being cramped black has the edge here.
right now the game is equal. Black is cramped but has some counterattack going. White has a space advantage but no serious attack. Dispute being cramped black has the edge here.

This is better than 12. Be2 or Qe2 because of white's weakness on g-file. For example if white continues:

12. Qe2 then 12. ...Qxe2 13. Bxe2 hxg4 14. hxg4 Bxg4 and then black will eventually switch his light bishop to e4 and push the f pawn down the white king's throat.
opening up the g-file
I am glad for the simplification because I was starting to get lost in the many lines available to black. The queens are off the board and Black has a favorable endgame.

I debated about 0-0-0 for awhile. In the end I did not think it would give me of anything of real value. The main reason why I decided not to castle was because f7 would be harder to defend if attacked. So 21. ...Ke7 still activates the rook plus it defends the f7 pawn
